comments.text:
so 3 eggs that my 9 year old daughter ate as a snack before the rest of dinner was served (happened just this week. she's hungry) plus an absurd amount of butter and from what i can tell even more creme fraiche, so it's eggs and gallojs of really greasy milk. oh and he never stopped stirring. truly masterful. couldnt have done that myself.

being a cook really is just being a house wife with slightly more expensive ingredients and using twice as many kinds than needed. add to it some extra work steps to make yourself look like you've really worked hard for the meal and that you had to learn for a very long time to perfect your skill, and your 3 star chef will be extraordinarily pleased.

my wife did this in less time using less effort and fewer ingredients whilst also looking after our baby while i was sick. sometimes i'd also give it a try, but i lack her skills and especially speed. it just makes more sense for me to do the laundry because i am stronger and run faster up and down the stairs 3 storeys, also lugging around the vacuum cleaner. but watching this gave me nothing to close the gap so she can eat sth good for a change when i have to cook for her when she's sick. i already know how to make scrambled eggs.

comments.text:
NO!
Who taught all these top chefs to make soupy goopy mealy eggs? Yuck. A good scrambled egg has curds that are large, moist, silky and tender. If you do scrambled eggs right, they are good even without butter/fat, because the yolk never reaches a temperature where it develops granular chalkiness (around 150f). Of course adding fat is great, not saying you shouldn't, just saying that all these chefs would be unable to give you a good scrambled egg if they ran out of butter. They also disrespect the curd.
NEVER DISRESPECT THE CURD!
TAKE BACK THE CURD!!

comments.text: British people are inherently bad at making food. Not to disrespect but like they really have low expectations from their food; I really respect them for it rather. Cook your meal without a fuss and go about your day. This guy is simply doing that but with arrogance and overconfident attitude and in my opinion, and agreeing to the fact that restaurant business takes basic culinary skill, consistency, and ethics, but I feel he has gaslightighed his way to earn this celebrity chef status. Yes being a celebrity is about being really average but filled with passion of stardom and an overconfident attitude. Not trying to demean anyone here and I think one should be happy where they are or strive to be wherever they want to be.  However lastly to be honest food is an emotional issue and apart from gaining and developing a few scientific trickery here and there, the most celebrated chef in the world cannot tell a person to make food this or that way if we talk about making basic dishes. One I saw him preaching Thai fried rice to Thai chefs and he couldn't take their criticism: a case of inflated ego.

If i need to make 20 orders in 5 mins how could i do what hes doing at 20 times the volume in 3 mins then keep doing that for like 5 hours?

comments.text:
Ugh, no. Way too creamy. It‚Äôs less scrambled eggs than egg mash. Sure, it‚Äôs a matter of preference‚Ä¶

I prefer to open the eggs into a bowl, lightly salt only the yolks (this way it‚Äôs easier to get the right amount), pepper the egg whites and add a splash of milk or cream. Add chives, if you want to. Scramble it all thoroughly with a fork.
Put a generous amount of butter in a non-stick pan on medium temp, so it‚Äôll melt but won‚Äôt get brown. Add the eggs, then push them from side to side with a spatula. Like ruining an omelette.
Anyway, get the pan off the heat while the eggs aren‚Äôt completely done yet. They should look rather moist and glisten.

comments.author: @adrianscarlett
comments.text:
3 eggs, salt, pepper, beat with a fork.
Hot pan, tiny bit of oil.
Pour in eggs, wait 20 seconds, stir slowly by scraping the edges and bottom.
Keep stirring until half cooked (another 20-30 seconds).
Take off heat and keep stirring.
Eggs should be 85-90% solid.
Serve.

Nothing else required, no butter, no creme fraiche. The eggs have all they need to taste amazing.

comments.text:
My mother just whisks the eggs. Not cold eggs. Just pick it up, crack it in a bowl then whisks.


After madly whisking the eggs, she puts it in the pan then waits for it to cook.

I have eaten her cooked eggs. They're cooked fine. So I don't understand the EXTRAVAGANCE of cooking an egg on and off the heat then adding creme fresh.


It's an egg. Just cook it as it is. This is like the foreigners understanding of Chicken. It is NEVER a Chicken when it has NO BONES. At best, it is a PROCESSED Chicken. Since a NATURAL Chicken WOULD HAVE BONES!


Chicken is the hardest to cook when compared to beef and pork. Because a REAL Chicken is cooked in the bone. You can leave a beef or pork in the pan and it will cook. Granted it is burnt but still it is cooked. Even if you burn a REAL Chicken, it is uncertain if it is cooked inside. Because of the PRESENCE of the BONE!

comments.author: @TheInstinctWithinV2
comments.text: I can do that without any added ingredients. Forget Gordon's advice here, go watch Gino from UK breakfast TV cook scrambled eggs. You put on the lowest heat, add butter or oil, whichever you prefer. Add the eggs and gently stir, make sure to never stop moving it, and never increase the heat because that will change the texture. Be patient. No creme fresche or anything needed. Soon enough you will have fluffy scrambled egg that you can transfer straight to the plate. Now you can add salt and pepper or any garnish you like. Very important, never add salt before it is finished because Salt early will turn the eggs gray and nasty. Enjoy.

I am a chef and I have never seen anyone cook eggs the way he did.
If I add butter I always melt it first. I would generally add a splash of milk to the eggs.
I always whisk the eggs first before adding them to the pan so the yolk and white don‚Äôt cook separately.
You don‚Äôt need to keep taking the pan off the heat, just put it on a lower heat.
I would have cooked them a bit more than he did.
Don‚Äôt know how he thinks those eggs are fluffy you have to whisk them to make them fluffy. Most scrambled eggs are meant to be soft and creamy.
His one is not like the one already made it is too runny. If I sent the egg like that the customer they would send them back.
Overall this is a bit sloppy considering it‚Äôs master chef.

comments.author: @yourchannelsux
comments.text: Not scrambled eggs in the modern sense, these are 'Scrambled Eggs a la Escoffier' named for the OG chef Auguste Escoffier. Gordon's version is slightly bastardized, but a decent interpretation of the classic. Originally Escoffier recommended cooking these in a bain Marie, saying that cooking time should be in the range of 40 minutes, but later acknowledged that preparation in a pan over heat could achieve similar results in less time given that the cook manages heat.

comments.text:
So "the perfect scrambled eggs" is just slightly lumpy, hyper-seasoned egg soup? with half a grove worth of chives hacked over it?
Hmmm. ü§î I knever knew...
No, but seriously, I truly believe a good quality sour cream is IMMENSLEY superior to friggen cReMe fRaiChe in scrambled eggs. It melts to a thicker consistency/per how much kick it gives to the egg, which means: a smaller amount does more, and your eggs won't resemble this pureed jellyfish, like Gordon's ScrEggs.
GORDON may like his screggs runny, packed with seasoning JUST so they have some actual flavour... because your needlessly posh creme fraiche has bugger all flavour.
That's why you have to put 5 tablespoons of chives over it with 14 twists of the pepper grinder....

JUST Because you're "aBoVe" using sour cream.
Only plebs use sour cream in screggs, if even at all, hey gOrDoN.

FTR, I totally respect (most) of Gordon's thing... but these eggs look like you could drink them with a straw.
Im an armchair scregg connoisseur, and I've made these, and theyre, definitely infirior to mine.

If you want a more mois scregg, dot add gubbins to the eggs, like dairy products, just time when you break the yolks ovet the cooking time and get the perfect consistency and texture by nature of the EGGS, not pointless creamy nonsense.
Nothing on the planet is creamier than a slowly cooked egg. Why ruin it with a curdling, superfluous dairy product?
So yea, Gordon should stop pretending to know Pad Thai, Carbonara, scrambled friggen eggs?
I mean,
Cmon... Gordy, bro. Snap out of it, lad.
